text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. title: Introduction to the TDCM Package
text: TDCM R package implements estimation longitudinal diagnostic classification models (DCMs) using transition diagnostic classification model (TDCM) framework described Madison & Bradshaw (2018). TDCM longitudinal extension log-linear cognitive diagnosis model (LCDM) developed Henson, Templin & Willse (2009). LCDM general DCM, many DCMs can embedded within TDCM. TDCM package includes functions estimate single group (TDCM::tdcm()) multigroup (TDCM::mg.tdcm()) TDCM summarize results interest, including: item parameter estimates, growth proportions, transition probabilities, transition reliability, attribute correlations, model fit, growth plots. Internally, TDCM package uses CDM::gdina() CDM package developed Robitzsch et al. (2022) estimate TDCMs using method described Madison et al. (2024). vignette provides overview package’s core functionality walking two examples. code can copied R console run. detailed video demonstrations package functionality, visit Matthew J. Madison’s Logitudinal DCMs page.

title: Introduction to the TDCM Package
text: estimate single group multigroup TDCM, use TDCM::tdcm() TDCM::mg.tdcm() functions, respectively. extract item, person, growth parameters TDCM estimates, use TDCM::tdcm.summary() TDCM::mg.tdcm.summary() functions single group multigroup analyses, respectively. summary functions produce list results include: item parameter estimates, growth proportions effect sizes, transition probability matrices, transition reliability, attribute correlations, model fit. compare models assess relative fit, use TDCM::tdcm.compare() function. plot results TDCM analysis, use TDCM::tdcm.plot() function. score responses using fixed item parameters previously calibrated model, use TDCM::tdcm.score() function.

title: Introduction to the TDCM Package
text: Different DCMs (e.g., LCDM, DINA, CRUM, GDINA) can modeled using TDCM::tdcm() function supplying argument rule linkfct parameters. DCM rule specification, package currently accepts “LCDM” (default), “DINA”, “DINO”, “CRUM”, “RRUM”, “LCDM2” LCDM two-way interactions, “LCDM3” LCDM three-way interactions, . Different link functions can specified linkfct parameter, including “logit” (default), “identity” obtain GDINA model, “log”. Using multiple Q-matrices time supported TDCM::tdcm() function. enable functionality, argument \(>=\) 2 must supplies num.q.matrix parameter, appropriately stacked Q-matrix must supplied q.matrix parameter. Anchor (common) items time points can specified anchor parameter. reduced transition space can implemented forget.att argument, attribute proficiency loss, forgetting, can constrained individual attributes. two time points, transitions can defined differently (e.g., first--last, first--, successive) transition.option parameter. Responses can scored using fixed item parameters previously calibrated model using TDCM::tdcm.score() function.

title: Introduction to the TDCM Package
text: summarize results, use TDCM::tdcm.summary()function. running summary function, can examine item parameters, growth attribute proficiency, transition probability matrices, individual transitions, transitional reliability estimates. demonstrate interpretation, let’s discuss results. Item 1 measuring 4.MD.1 intercept estimate -1.905 main effect estimate -2.072. respect growth, see students exhibited amount growth 4.MD.1, 4.MD.2, 4.MD.3 (18.03% growth proficiency), showed larger gains 4.MD.4 (45.1%). Examining 4.MD.1 transition probability matrix, see students started non-proficiency, 32% transitioned proficiency. Examining individual transition posterior probabilities, see Examinee 1 mostly likely transition 0 → 1 (0.999 probability). Finally, transition reliability appears adequate, average maximum transition posteriors ranging .88 .92 four attributes.

what: The Transition Diagnostic Classification Model Framework
title: The Transition Diagnostic Classification Model Framework
text: ‘TDCM’ R package lets users estimate transition diagnostic classification model (TDCM) described Madison & Bradshaw (2018), longitudinal extension log-linear cognitive diagnosis model (LCDM) Henson, Templin & Willse (2009). LCDM subsumes many diagnostic classification models (DCMs), many DCMs can estimated longitudinally via TDCM framework. ‘TDCM’ package includes functions estimate single-group multigroup TDCM, summarize results interest including item parameters, growth proportions, transition probabilities, transitional reliability, attribute correlations, model fit, growth plots.

title: The Transition Diagnostic Classification Model Framework
text: can install ‘TDCM’ package like :
code: # Install the latest development version of TDCM from GitHub: if (!require("devtools")) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("cotterell/tdcm")

what: The Transition Diagnostic Classification Model Framework — TDCM-package
title: The Transition Diagnostic Classification Model Framework — TDCM-package
text: R package TDCM enables longitudinal diagnostic classification model (DCM) analyses within transition diagnostic classification model (TDCM) framework.

title: The Transition Diagnostic Classification Model Framework — TDCM-package
text: Diagnostic classification models (DCMs) psychometric models designed classify examinees according proficiency set categorical latent traits, known attributes. Longitudinal DCMs developed psychometric options modeling changes attribute proficiency time. TDCM implements estimation transition DCM (TDCM; Madison & Bradshaw, 2018a), longitudinal extension log-linear cognitive diagnosis model (LCDM; Henson, Templin, & Willse, 2009). LCDM subsumes many DCMs, many DCMs can estimated longitudinally via TDCM. package includes functions estimate single-group multigroup TDCM, summarize results interest including item parameters, growth proportions, transition probabilities, transitional reliability, attribute correlations, model fit, growth plots. details examples, see vignette("TDCM", package = "TDCM").

title: Estimating item influence measures. — item.influence
text: list containing several item influence measures.

title: Estimating item influence measures. — item.influence
text: DCMs, item influence quantifies much item impacts classifications. Given estimated DCM item response data, function estimates five item influence measures, including item pull, item override, proportion attribute information, response-classification correlation (corr1), response-posterior correlation (corr2).

title: Estimating the multigroup transition diagnostic classification model (TDCM) — mg.tdcm
text: mg.tdcm() estimates Transition Diagnostic Classification Model scenarios involving multiple groups (e.g., control treatment group; Madison & Bradshaw, 2018b). Similar tdcm(), function supports estimation various DCMs allowing different rule specifications via rule option link functions via linkfct option,LCDM default rule link function. rule can modified estimate DINA model, DINO model, CRUM (.e., ACDM, main effects model), reduced interaction versions LCDM. Additionally, link function can adjusted specify GDINA model.

title: Estimating the multigroup transition diagnostic classification model (TDCM) — mg.tdcm
code: mg.tdcm(   data,   q.matrix,   num.time.points,   rule = "LCDM",   linkfct = "logit",   groups,   forget.att = c(),   group.invariance = TRUE,   time.invariance = TRUE,   progress = TRUE )

title: Estimating the multigroup transition diagnostic classification model (TDCM) — mg.tdcm
text: data required \(N \times T \times \) matrix data.frame rows correspond N examinees columns represent binary item responses across T time points items. q.matrix required \(\times \) matrix indicating items measure attributes. Currently, function accepts single Q-matrix. num.time.points required integer \(\ge 2\) specifying number time points (.e., measurement occasions). rule string vector indicating specific DCM employed. vector supported rule values provided tdcm.rules. Currently accepted values : "LCDM", "DINA", "DINO", "CRUM", "RRUM", "LCDM1" LCDM main effects, "LCDM2" LCDM two-way interactions, "LCDM3", . rule supplied single string, DCM assumed item. entered vector, rule can specified item. vector must length equal total number items across time points. linkfct string vector indicating LCDM link function. Currently accepts "logit" (default) estimate LCDM, "identity" estimate GDINA model, "log" link function estimate reduced reparameterized unified model (RRUM). vector must length equal total number items across time points. groups required vector integer group identifiers multiple group estimation. forget.att optional vector allowing constraining individual attribute proficiency loss, forgetting. default allows forgetting measured attribute (e.g., \(P(1 \rightarrow 0) \neq 0\)). See tdcm detailed information. group.invariance logical argument. TRUE (default), item parameters assumed equal groups. FALSE, item parameters assumed equal groups. time.invariance logical argument. TRUE (default), item parameters assumed equal time points. FALSE, item parameters assumed equal time points. progress logical argument. FALSE, function print progress estimation. TRUE (default), progress information printed.

title: Estimating the multigroup transition diagnostic classification model (TDCM) — mg.tdcm
text: Multigroup Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (Multigroup TDCM) Multigroup TDCM confirmatory latent transition model measures examinees' growth decline attribute mastery time among groups (Madison & Bradshaw, 2018b). model, probability item response vector \(X_e\) conditioned observed groups membership \(G\): $$ P(X_e = x_e|G=g) = \sum_{c_1=1}^{C} \sum_{c_2=1}^{C} \cdots \sum_{c_T=1}^{C} v_{c_1|g} \tau_{c_2 | c_{1},g} \tau_{c_3 | c_{2},g} \cdots \tau_{c_T | c_{T-1},g} \prod_{t=1}^{T} \prod_{=1}^{} \pi_{c_{t,g}}^{x_{eit}} (1 - \pi_{c_{t,g}})^{1 - x_{eit}}, $$ : \(v_{c_1|g}\) represents probability belonging attribute profile \(c\) time 1 given observed group \(g\). \(\tau_{c_t | c_{T-1},g}\) represents probability transitioning attribute profiles time point \(t-1\) time point \(t\). \(\pi_{ic_{t,g}}\) item response function, models probability answering item \(\) correctly time \(t\) given attribute profile \(c\) observed group \(g\). Therefore, study purpose assess growth treatment control group pre- post-test design, probability item response vector reduces : $$ P(X_e = x_e|G=g) = \sum_{c_1=1}^{C} \sum_{c_2=1}^{C} v_{c_1|g} \tau_{c_2 | c_{1,g}} \prod_{t=1}^{2} \prod_{=1}^{} \pi_{c_{t,g}}^{x_{eit}} (1 - \pi_{c_{t,g}})^{1 - x_{eit}}. $$ Accounting Measurement Invariance Measurement invariance indicates whether item response function remains constant time points (time invariance) across groups (group invariance). Note regardless assumed invariance, attribute mastery transitions can still compared across time groups. Depending assumed constrained, one four measurement invariance conditions can applied: Consider experiment design treatment control group.

what: a) No time Invariance across time or group invariance assumed
title: Estimating the multigroup transition diagnostic classification model (TDCM) — mg.tdcm
text: neither time group invariance assumed, item different response function time across groups. Thus, probability item response function remains unchanged. $$ P(X_e = x_e|G=g) = \sum_{c_1=1}^{C} \sum_{c_2=1}^{C} v_{c_1|g} \tau_{c_2 | c_{1}, g} \prod_{t=1}^{2} \prod_{=1}^{} \pi_{c_{t,g}}^{x_{eit}} (1 - \pi_{c_{t,g}})^{1 - x_{eit}}. $$

what: b) No time Invariance across time assumed but group invariance assumed
title: Estimating the multigroup transition diagnostic classification model (TDCM) — mg.tdcm
text: time invariance assumed group invariance , item different response function time. Thus, probability item response function depends \(t\). $$ P(X_e = x_e|G=g) = \sum_{c_1=1}^{C} \sum_{c_2=1}^{C} v_{c_1|g} \tau_{c_2 | c_{1}, g} \prod_{t=1}^{2} \prod_{=1}^{} \pi_{c_{t}}^{x_{eit}} (1 - \pi_{c_{t}})^{1 - x_{eit}}. $$

what: c) Time Invariance across time assumed but not group invariance
title: Estimating the multigroup transition diagnostic classification model (TDCM) — mg.tdcm
text: time invariance assumed group invariance , item different response function across groups. Thus, probability item response function depends \(g\). $$ P(X_e = x_e|G=g) = \sum_{c_1=1}^{C} \sum_{c_2=1}^{C} v_{c_1|g} \tau_{c_2 | c_{1}, g} \prod_{t=1}^{2} \prod_{=1}^{} \pi_{c_{g}}^{x_{eit}} (1 - \pi_{c_{g}})^{1 - x_{eit}}. $$

what: d) Time Invariance across time and group invariance assumed
title: Estimating the multigroup transition diagnostic classification model (TDCM) — mg.tdcm
text: Finally, time group invariance assumed, item item response function time groups, reducing measurement model LCDM. $$ P(X_e = x_e|G=g) = \sum_{c_1=1}^{C} \sum_{c_2=1}^{C} v_{c_1|g} \tau_{c_2 | c_{1,g}} \prod_{t=1}^{2} \prod_{=1}^{} \pi_{c}^{x_{eit}} (1 - \pi_{c})^{1 - x_{eit}}. $$

what: Multigroup TDCM results compiler and summarizer — mg.tdcm.summary
title: Multigroup TDCM results compiler and summarizer — mg.tdcm.summary
text: Function summarize results obtained mg.tdcm function. includes information regarding item parameters, attribute posterior probabilities, transition posterior probabilities, attribute mastery classifications, growth, growth effects,transition probabilities, attribute correlations, model fit statistics, several transition reliability metrics developed Templin Bradshaw (2013) Johnson Sinharay (2020).

title: Multigroup TDCM results compiler and summarizer — mg.tdcm.summary
code: mg.tdcm.summary(   model,   transition.option = 1,   classthreshold = 0.5,   attribute.names = c(),   group.names = c() )

title: Multigroup TDCM results compiler and summarizer — mg.tdcm.summary
text: model tdcm object returned mg.tdcm function. transition.option optional argument specify transition probabilities reported attribute Q-matrix across time points. transition.option = 1 (default): Summarizes transition probabilities comparing first last time point. transition.option = 2: Summarizes transition comparing first time point every subsequent time point. transition.option = 3: summarizes transition probabilities comparing consecutive time point sequentially. classthreshold numeric value 0 1 specifying probability threshold determining examinees' proficiency based posterior probabilities. default value .50, optimizes overall classification accuracy. Lower values reduce probability false negatives, fewer mastery examinees misclassified non-proficient. Higher values reduce probability false positives, fewer non-master examinees misclassified proficient. attribute.names optional character vector specifying attribute names included plots. default, attribute.names=NULL, uses generic attribute labels Q-matrix. group.names optional character vector specifying group names included plots. default, group.names=NULL, uses generic group label based number groups model (e.g., Group 1, Group 2, etc).

title: Multigroup TDCM results compiler and summarizer — mg.tdcm.summary
text: list following items: $item.parameters: Item parameter estimates (logit) specified DCM. $growth: Proficiency proportions time point attribute. $growth.effects: includes three growth effect size metrics attribute specified transitions: Growth: Difference proficiency proportions later earlier time point. Odds Ratio: Ratio proficiency odds later time point proficiency odds earlier time point. Cohen's h (Cohen, 1988): Arcsine-transformed difference proficiency proportions. Note growth.effect output directly depend option specified transition.option. Example: Suppose test measures two attributes three time points. two time points, growth effect output calculated based option specified transition.option. transition.option=1, growth effect Attribute 1 2 computed time point 1 (earlier) time point 3 (latter). transition.option=2, growth effect Attribute 1 2 computed : Time point 1 (earlier) time point 2 (latter). Time point 1 (earlier) time point 3 (latter). transition.option=3, growth effect Attribute 1 2 obtained : Time point 1 (earlier) time point 2 (latter). Time point 2 (earlier), time point 3 (latter). $transition.probabilities: Conditional attribute proficiency transition probability matrices. $posterior.probabilities: Examinee marginal attribute posterior probabilities proficiency. $transition.posteriors: Examinee marginal attribute transition posterior probabilities. $.likely.transitions: Examinee likely transitions attribute transition. $classifications: Examinee classifications determined specified threshold applied posterior probabilities. $reliability: Estimated transition reliability metrics attribute specified transitions option specified. includes seven metrics: pt bis: Longitudinal point biserial metric, reflects ratio estimated attribute proficiency base rates attribute proficiency posterior probabilities. info gain: Longitudinal information gain metric. quantifies much additional information gained regarding attribute's transition time. polychor: Longitudinal tetrachoric metric. quantifies consistently examinee transitions mastery states two time points. ave max tr: Average maximum transition posterior metric. quantities likely examinee classified specific transition state time. P(t > k): Proportion examinees whose marginal attribute transition posteriors exceed threshold k. thresholds used k = 0.6, 0.7, 0.8, 0.9, representing proportion examinees attribute transition posterior probabilities greater values. example, P(t>.6) = 0.90, 90% examinees posterior probability greater 0.6. wt pt bis: Weighted longitudinal point biserial. variation longitudinal point biserial metric computes correlation true attribute transition classification observed marginal transition probabilities. assigns greater weight prevalent attribute transitions based attributes' transition base rate, ensuring transitions occurring frequently data contribute significantly computed reliability value. wt info gain: Weighted longitudinal information gain. variation longitudinal information gain quantifies additional information provided attribute transition posterior probabilities predicting examinees' true transition status. assigns greater weight prevalent attribute transitions, ensuring transitions occurring frequently data contribute significantly computed reliability value. $att.corr: Estimated attribute correlation matrix. $model.fit: Several model fit indices tests output including: Item root mean square error approximation (RMSEA; von Davier, 2005). Mean RMSEA. Bivariate item fit statistics (Chen et al., 2013). Absolute fit statistics mean absolute deviation observed. Expected item correlations (MADcor; DiBello, Roussos, & Stout, 2007). Standardized root mean square root squared residuals (SRMSR; Maydeu-Olivares, 2013).

title: Comparing the fit of two TDCMs — tdcm.compare
code: tdcm.compare(model1, model2)

title: Comparing the fit of two TDCMs — tdcm.compare

title: Comparing the fit of two TDCMs — tdcm.compare

title: Comparing the fit of two TDCMs — tdcm.compare

Please ensure models nested interpreting likelihood ratio test nested models. likelihood ratio test valid model comparisons (e.g., LCDM vs DINA) model constraints.

title: Comparing the fit of two TDCMs — tdcm.compare

what: Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
title: Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
text: tdcm() estimates transition diagnostic classification model (TDCM; Madison & Bradshaw, 2018a), longitudinal extension log-linear cognitive diagnosis model (LCDM; Henson, Templin, & Willse, 2009). multigroup TDCM, see mg.tdcm(). function supports estimation various longitudinal DCMs allowing different rule specifications via rule option link functions via linkfct option, LCDM default rule link function. rule can modified estimate DINA model, DINO model, CRUM (.e., ACDM, main effects model), reduced interaction versions LCDM. Additionally, link function can adjusted specify GDINA model.

title: Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
code: tdcm(   data,   q.matrix,   num.time.points,   invariance = TRUE,   rule = "LCDM",   linkfct = "logit",   num.q.matrix = 1,   num.items = c(),   anchor = c(),   forget.att = c(),   progress = TRUE )

title: Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
text: data required \(N \times T \times \) matrix data.frame rows correspond N examinees columns represent binary item responses across T time points items. q.matrix required \(\times \) matrix indicating items measure attributes. multiple Q-matrices, must number attributes must stacked top estimation (specify multiple Q-matrices, see num.q.matrix, num.items, anchor). num.time.points required integer \(\ge 2\) specifying number time points (.e., measurement occasions). invariance logical. TRUE (default), item parameters constrained equal time point. FALSE, item parameters assumed equal time. rule string vector indicating specific DCM employed. vector supported rule values provided tdcm.rules. Currently accepted values : "LCDM", "DINA", "DINO", "CRUM", "RRUM", "LCDM1" LCDM main effects, "LCDM2" LCDM two-way interactions, "LCDM3", . rule supplied single string, DCM assumed item. entered vector, rule can specified item. rule vector must length equal total number items across time points. linkfct string vector indicating LCDM link function. Currently accepts "logit" (default) estimate LCDM, "identity" estimate GDINA model, "log" link function estimate reduced reparameterized unified model (RRUM). link function vector must length equal total number items across time points. num.q.matrix optional integer specifying number Q-matrices. many applications, assessment administered time point number 1 (default). different Q-matrices time point, argument must specified equal number time points. example, three time points, Q-matrices time point different, num.q.matrix = 3. three time points, Q-matrix different time point 3, num.q.matrix still specified 3. num.items integer specifying number items. multiple Q-matrices, number items Q-matrix specified vector. example, three time points, Q-matrices time point 8, 10, 12 items, respectively. num.items = c(8, 10, 12). anchor optional vector specifying items linked across time points maintain item invariance different tests administered. default, anchor empty vector, indicating absence anchor items. Note: anchor specified, invariance automatically set FALSE non-anchor items. pair anchor vector consists reference item linked item, linked item mapped corresponding reference item. reference item necessarily appear first test; can time point. Example: Suppose three different 10-item tests corresponding Q-matrices. However, items remain across time points: Item 1 (first test), Item 11 (second test), Item 21 (third test) correspond item. Since Item 1 serves reference, Items 11 21  can linked using: anchor = c(1, 11, 1, 21) additionally assume Item 14 (second test) Item 24 (third test) correspond item, Item 14 serves reference, Item 24 linked . Thus, final anchor vector specified : anchor = c(1, 11, 1, 21, 14, 24) forget.att optional vector allowing constraining individual attribute proficiency loss, forgetting. default, forgetting allowed measured attributes, meaning probability transitioning mastery non-mastery can different zero (\(P(1 \rightarrow 0) \neq 0\)). vector attributes provided, \(P(1 \rightarrow 0) = 0\) specific attributes, meaning forgetting permitted. example, forget.att= c(2,4), forgetting Attributes 2 4 allowed, attributes can exhibit forgetting. progress logical. FALSE, function print progress estimation. TRUE (default), progress information printed.

title: Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
text: object class gdina entries described CDM::gdina(). see TDCM-specific summary object (e.g.,growth, transitions), use tdcm.summary().

title: Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
text: Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) TDCM confirmatory constrained latent transition model measures examinees' growth decline attribute mastery time (Madison & Bradshaw, 2018a). Assume \(X_{eit}\) corresponds binary response examinee \(e \\{1, \dots, N\}\) item \(\\{1, \dots, \}\) across time points \(t \\{1, \dots, T\}\), \(A_t\) denotes number attributes measured time \(t\). probability item response vector \(X_e = (x_{e11}, x_{e12}, \dots, x_{e1I}, x_{e21}, \dots, x_{eTI})\) given : $$ P(X_e = x_e) = \sum_{c_1=1}^{C} \sum_{c_2=1}^{C} \cdots \sum_{c_T=1}^{C} v_{c_1} \tau_{c_2 | c_1} \tau_{c_3 | c_2} \cdots \tau_{c_T | c_{T-1}} \prod_{t=1}^{T} \prod_{=1}^{} \pi_{c_t}^{x_{eit}} (1 - \pi_{c_t})^{1 - x_{eit}}, $$ : \(v_{c_1}\) represents probability belonging attribute profile \(c\) time 1. \(\tau_{c_t | c_{t-1}}\) represents probability transitioning attribute profiles time point \(t-1\) time point \(t\). \(\pi_{ic_t}\) item response function, models probability answering item \(\) correctly time \(t\) given attribute profile \(c\). Model Assumptions Variations 1. Accounting Measurement Invariance Measurement invariance indicates whether item response function remains consistent time changes across time points. Depending testing conditions, different measurement invariance assumptions can assumed:

title: Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
text: measurement invariance assumed (default option), items maintain constant response function across time: \(\forall \, \pi_{c_1}=\pi_{c_2} = \dots = \pi_{c_T}\), \(\forall t \T\). Therefore, probability item response vector simplifies : $$ P(X_e = x_e) = \sum_{c_1=1}^{C} \sum_{c_2=1}^{C} \cdots \sum_{c_T=1}^{C} v_{c_1} \tau_{c_3 | c_2} \cdots \tau_{c_T | c_{T-1}} \prod_{t=1}^{T} \prod_{=1}^{} \pi_{c}^{x_{eit}} (1 - \pi_{c})^{1 - x_{eit}}, $$ $$   \pi_{ic} = P(X_{ic} = 1|\alpha_{c}) = \frac{exp(\lambda_{,0}+   \boldsymbol{\lambda_{}^T}   \boldsymbol{h(\alpha_{c}, q_i)})}{1 + exp(\lambda_{,0}+   \boldsymbol{\lambda_{}^T} \boldsymbol{h(\alpha_{c}, q_i)})},    $$ : \(q_i\) Q-matrix item \(\). Recall item across time points measurement invariance assumed, Q-matrix also remain across time. \(\lambda_{,0}\) intercept parameter item \(\). \(\boldsymbol{h(\alpha_{c_t}, q_i)}\) function mapping attribute profile \(\alpha_{c}\) item Q-matrix.

title: Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
text: measurement invariance partially assumed, items (anchor items) maintain item response function across time points, others (non-anchor items) vary time. Assume \(\B\) anchor items, \(\forall \B, \forall t \T, \pi_{c_1}=\pi_{c_2} = \dots = \pi_{c_T}\). implies anchor items measure attributes across time corresponding Q-matrix entries remain unchanged. Assume also \(\Z\) non-anchor items, \(\forall \Z, \forall t \\{2, \dots, T\}, \pi_{c_t} \neq \pi_{c_{t-1}}\). means non-anchor items may change across time measure different attributes, leading changes corresponding Q-matrix entries. , probability item response vector : $$ P(X_e = x_e) = \sum_{c_1=1}^{C} \sum_{c_2=1}^{C} \cdots \sum_{c_T=1}^{C} v_{c_1} \tau_{c_2 | c_1} \tau_{c_3 | c_2} \cdots \tau_{c_T | c_{T-1}} \prod_{t=1}^{T} \prod_{\B} \pi_{c}^{x_{eit}} (1 - \pi_{c})^{1 - x_{eit}} \prod_{t=1}^{T} \prod_{\Z} \pi_{c_t}^{x_{eit}} (1 - \pi_{c_t})^{1 - x_{eit}}. $$

title: Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
text: Unlike standard latent transition models assume monotonic learning,TDCM allows mastery acquisition forgetting. default, TDCM impose mastery must always increase time. Instead, transition probabilities \(\tau_{c_t | c_{t-1}}\) examinee \(e\) can represent transition : transition non-mastery status master attribute status (learning). transition master attribute status non-mastery status (forgetting). However, TDCM also allows attribute-specific constrains, enabling restrict transition probabilities certain attributes. 3. Special Cases TDCM, item response function \(\pi_{ic_{t}}\) parameterized using LCDM. LCDM general flexible model allows special models derived constraining specific parameters.

title: Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
text: DINA model non-compensatory DCM, meaning examinees can correctly answer item mastered attributes required item. Given characteristic, DINA model derived constraining main effects LCDM zero, highest-order interaction term influences item response probability.

title: Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
text: Suppose item 1 measures Attributes 1 2, item invariance assumed across time points. item response function item 1 following LCDM can expressed : $$ \pi_{1c} = P(X_{1c} = 1|\alpha_{c}) = \frac{exp(\lambda_{1,0}+ \lambda_{1,1(1)}\alpha_{c1} + \lambda_{1,1(2)}\alpha_{c2} + \lambda_{1,2(1,2)}\alpha_{c1}\alpha_{c2})}{1 + exp(\lambda_{1,0}+ \lambda_{1,1(1)}\alpha_{c1} + \lambda_{1,1(2)}\alpha_{c2} + \lambda_{1,2(1,2)}\alpha_{c1}\alpha_{c2})}, $$ , DINA model obtained constraining LCDM main effects zero, resulting : $$ \pi_{1c} = P(X_{1c} = 1|\alpha_{c}) = \frac{exp(\lambda_{1,0}+ \lambda_{1,2(1,2)}\alpha_{c1}\alpha_{c2})}{1 + exp(\lambda_{1,0}+ \lambda_{1,2(1,2)}\alpha_{c1}\alpha_{c2})}. $$

title: Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
text: DINO model compensatory DCM, meaning examinees can correctly answer item mastered least one attributes required item. Consequently, main interaction terms LCDM constrained equal, subtract interaction term ensure item response probability remains unchanged multiple attributes mastered. Following previous example, DINO model can expressed : $$ \pi_{1c} = P(X_{1c} = 1|\alpha_{c}) = \frac{exp(\lambda_{1,0}+ (\lambda_{1,1(1)}\alpha_{c1} + \lambda_{1,1(2)}\alpha_{c2} - \lambda_{1,2(1,2)}\alpha_{c1}\alpha_{c2}))}{1 + exp(\lambda_{1,0}+ (\lambda_{1,1(1)}\alpha_{c1} + \lambda_{1,1(2)}\alpha_{c2} - \lambda_{1,2(1,2)}\alpha_{c1}\alpha_{c2}))}. $$

title: Estimating the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm
text: CRUM compensatory DCM attribute independently contributes probability correct response. Unlike DINO model, mastering multiple attributes neither penalizes provides additional advantage. Thus, probability correct response determined solely sum individual main effects, constraining interaction term zero. Following previous example, CRUM model can expressed : $$ \pi_{1c} = P(X_{1c} = 1|\alpha_{c}) = \frac{exp(\lambda_{1,0}+ \lambda_{1,1(1)}\alpha_{c1} + \lambda_{1,1(2)}\alpha_{c2} )}{1 + exp(\lambda_{1,0}+ \lambda_{1,1(1)}\alpha_{c1} + \lambda_{1,1(2)}\alpha_{c2} )}. $$ Estimation methods Estimation TDCM via CDM package (George, et al., 2016), based EM algorithm described de la Torre (2011). estimation approach detailed Madison et al. (2023).

# Example 3: TDCM with different Q-matrices for each time point and no # anchor items ############################################################################  # Load dataset: T=3, A=2 data(data.tdcm03, package = "TDCM") data <- data.tdcm03$data q1 <- data.tdcm03$q.matrix.1 q2 <- data.tdcm03$q.matrix.2 q3 <- data.tdcm03$q.matrix.3 q <- data.tdcm03$q.matrix.stacked  # Estimate model model3 <- TDCM::tdcm(data, q, num.time.points = 3, rule = "LCDM",                     num.q.matrix = 3, num.items = c(10, 10, 10)) #> [1] Preparing data for tdcm()... #> [1] Estimating the TDCM in tdcm()... #> [1] Depending on model complexity, estimation time may vary... #> [1] TDCM estimation complete. #> [1] Use tdcm.summary() to display results.  #---------------------------------------------------------------------------- # Summarize results with tdcm.summary() for more than 2 time points. #----------------------------------------------------------------------------  ## There are three post hoc approaches to summarize the transition probabilities ## for each attribute across time using the tdcm.summary() function. ## Each of them is illustrated below.  ## 1. When the transition.option argument in the tdcm.summary() is not specified, ## the function assumes by default that transition.option = 1. ## Thus, when summarizing the transition probabilities ## you will compare the results for the first and last time point.  ### Summary with default option  results3_def_transition <- TDCM::tdcm.summary(model3) #> [1] Summarizing results... #> [1] Routine finished. Check results. results3_def_transition$transition.probabilities #> , , Attribute 1: Time 1 to Time 3 #>  #>        T3 [0] T3 [1] #> T1 [0]  0.202  0.798 #> T1 [1]  0.146  0.854 #>  #> , , Attribute 2: Time 1 to Time 3 #>  #>        T3 [0] T3 [1] #> T1 [0]  0.325  0.675 #> T1 [1]  0.257  0.743 #>  #, , Attribute 1: Time 1 to Time 3 # #       T3 [0] T3 [1] #T1 [0]  0.202  0.798 #T1 [1]  0.146  0.854 # #, , Attribute 2: Time 1 to Time 3 # #       T3 [0] T3 [1] #T1 [0]  0.325  0.675 #T1 [1]  0.257  0.743  ## 2. When the transition.option = 2, you can compare the transition probabilities ## from the first time point to every other time point. In this case, you can ## compare the transition probabilities between Time Point 1 and Time Point 2, ## and Time Point 1 with Time Point 3.  ### Summary with transition.option = 2 results3_2transition <- TDCM::tdcm.summary(model3, transition.option = 2) #> [1] Summarizing results... #> [1] Routine finished. Check results. results3_2transition$transition.probabilities #> , , Attribute 1: Time 1 to Time 2 #>  #>       [0]   [1] #> [0] 0.510 0.490 #> [1] 0.424 0.576 #>  #> , , Attribute 2: Time 1 to Time 2 #>  #>       [0]   [1] #> [0] 0.456 0.544 #> [1] 0.334 0.666 #>  #> , , Attribute 1: Time 1 to Time 3 #>  #>       [0]   [1] #> [0] 0.202 0.798 #> [1] 0.146 0.854 #>  #> , , Attribute 2: Time 1 to Time 3 #>  #>       [0]   [1] #> [0] 0.325 0.675 #> [1] 0.257 0.743 #>  #, , Attribute 1: Time 1 to Time 2 # #.    [0]   [1] #[0] 0.510 0.490 #[1] 0.424 0.576 # #, , Attribute 2: Time 1 to Time 2 # #     [0]   [1] #[0] 0.456 0.544 #[1] 0.334 0.666 # #, , Attribute 1: Time 1 to Time 3 # #     [0]   [1] #[0] 0.202 0.798 #[1] 0.146 0.854 # #, , Attribute 2: Time 1 to Time 3 # #     [0]   [1] #[0] 0.325 0.675 #[1] 0.257 0.743  ## 3. When the transition.option = 3, you can compare the transition probabilities ## sequentially, such that for each attribute, you can compare the transition ## probabilities between Time Point 1 and Time Point 2, Time Point 2 and Time Point 3  ### Summary with transition.option = 3 results3_3transition <- TDCM::tdcm.summary(model3, transition.option = 3) #> [1] Summarizing results... #> [1] Routine finished. what: Assessing item parameter drift (IPD) in the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm.ipd
title: Assessing item parameter drift (IPD) in the Transition Diagnostic Classification Model (TDCM) — tdcm.ipd
text: tdcm.ipd() function assesses item parameter drift (IPD) TDCM (e.g., Madison & Bradshaw, 2018) applying Wald test differential item functioning (de la Torre, 2011; Hou, de la Torre & Nandakumar, 2014). p-values also calculated Holm adjustment multiple comparisons. case two time points, effect size item parameter drift (labeled UA ipd.stats value) defined weighted absolute difference item response functions.

(2011). Generalized DINA model framework. Psychometrika, 76, 179–199. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11336-011-9207-7. Hou, L., de la Torre, J., & Nandakumar, R. (2014). Differential item functioning assessment cognitive diagnostic modeling: Application Wald test investigate DIF DINA model. Journal Educational Measurement, 51, 98-125. https://doi.org/10.1111/jedm.12036. Madison, M. J., & Bradshaw, L. (2018a). Assessing growth diagnostic classification model framework. Psychometrika, 83(4), 963-990. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11336-018-9638-5.

what: TDCM results compiler and summarizer. — tdcm.summary
title: TDCM results compiler and summarizer. — tdcm.summary
text: Function summarize results obtained tdcm function. includes information regarding item parameters, attribute posterior probabilities, transition posterior probabilities, attribute mastery classifications, growth, growth effects,transition probabilities, attribute correlations, model fit statistics, several transition reliability metrics developed Schellman Madison (2024).

title: TDCM results compiler and summarizer. — tdcm.summary
code: tdcm.summary(   model,   transition.option = 1,   classthreshold = 0.5,   attribute.names = c() )

title: TDCM results compiler and summarizer. — tdcm.summary
text: model tdcm object returned tdcm function. transition.option optional argument specify growth transition probabilities reported attribute across time points. transition.option = 1 (default): Summarizes transition probabilities comparing first last time point. transition.option = 2: Summarizes transition comparing first time point every subsequent time point. transition.option = 3: Summarizes transition probabilities comparing consecutive time point sequentially. classthreshold numeric value 0 1 specifying probability threshold determining examinees' proficiency based posterior probabilities. default value .50, optimizes overall classification accuracy. Lower values reduce probability false negatives, fewer proficient examinees misclassified non-proficient. Higher values reduce probability false positives, fewer non-proficient examinees misclassified proficient. attribute.names optional character vector specifying attribute names included results outputs. default, attribute.names=NULL, uses generic attribute labels Q-matrix.

title: TDCM results compiler and summarizer. — tdcm.summary
text: list following items: $item.parameters: Item parameter estimates specified DCM. $growth: Proficiency proportions time point attribute. $growth.effects: includes three growth effect size metrics attribute specified transitions: Growth: Difference proficiency proportions later earlier time point. Odds Ratio: Ratio proficiency odds later time point proficiency odds earlier time point. Cohen's h (Cohen, 1988): Arcsine-transformed difference proficiency proportions. Note growth.effect output directly depend option specified transition.option. Example: Suppose test measures two attributes three time points. two time points, growth effect output calculated based option specified transition.option. transition.option=1, growth effect Attribute 1 2 computed Time Point 1 (first) Time Point 3 (last). transition.option=2, growth effect Attribute 1 2 computed : Time Point 1 (first) Time Point 2 (latter). Time Point 1 (first) Time Point 3 (latter). transition.option=3, growth effect Attribute 1 2 obtained : Time Point 1 (earlier) Time Point 2 (next). Time Point 2 (earlier), Time Point 3 (next). $transition.probabilities: Conditional attribute proficiency transition probability matrices. $posterior.probabilities: Examinee marginal attribute posterior probabilities proficiency. $transition.posteriors: Examinee marginal attribute transition posterior probabilities. $.likely.transitions: Examinee likely transitions attribute transition. $classifications: Examinee classifications determined specified threshold applied posterior probabilities. $reliability: Estimated transition reliability metrics attribute specified transitions option specified (Madison, 2019; Schellman & Madison, 2024). includes seven metrics: pt bis: Longitudinal point biserial metric, reflects ratio estimated attribute proficiency base rates attribute proficiency posterior probabilities. info gain: Longitudinal information gain metric. quantifies much additional information gained regarding attribute's transition time. polychor: Longitudinal tetrachoric metric. quantifies consistently examinee transitions mastery states two time points. ave max tr: Average maximum transition posterior metric. quantities likely examinee classified specific transition state time. P(t > k): Proportion examinees whose marginal attribute transition posteriors exceed threshold k. thresholds used k = 0.6, 0.7, 0.8, 0.9, representing proportion examinees attribute transition posterior probabilities greater values. example, P(t>.6) = 0.90, 90% examinees posterior probability greater 0.6. wt pt bis: Weighted longitudinal point biserial. variation longitudinal point biserial metric computes correlation true attribute transition classification observed marginal transition probabilities. assigns greater weight prevalent attribute transitions based attributes' transition base rate, ensuring transitions occurring frequently data contribute significantly computed reliability value. wt info gain: Weighted longitudinal information gain. variation longitudinal information gain quantifies additional information provided attribute transition posterior probabilities predicting examinees' true transition status. assigns greater weight prevalent attribute transitions, ensuring transitions occurring frequently data contribute significantly computed reliability value. $att.corr: Estimated attribute correlation matrix. $model.fit: Several model fit indices tests output including: Item root mean square error approximation (RMSEA; von Davier, 2005). Mean item RMSEA. Bivariate item fit statistics (Chen et al., 2013). Absolute fit statistics mean absolute deviation observed. Expected item correlations (MADcor; DiBello, Roussos, & Stout, 2007). Standardized root mean square root squared residuals (SRMSR; Maydeu-Olivares, 2013).

title: TDCM results compiler and summarizer. — tdcm.summary
text: Chen, J., de la Torre, J., & Zhang, Z. (2013). Relative absolute fit evaluation cognitive diagnosis modeling. Journal Educational Measurement, 50, 123-140. Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical Power Analysis Behavioral Sciences (2nd ed.). Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Publishers. DiBello, L. V., Roussos, L. ., & Stout, W. F. (2007). Review cognitively diagnostic assessment summary psychometric models. C. R. Rao S. Sinharay (Eds.), Handbook Statistics, Vol. 26 (pp.979–1030). Amsterdam: Elsevier. Johnson, M. S., & Sinharay, S. (2020). reliability posterior probability skill attainment diagnostic classification models. Journal Educational Measurement, 47(1), 5 – 31. Madison, M. J. (2019). Reliably assessing growth longitudinal diagnostic classification models. Educational Measurement: Issues Practice, 38(2), 68-78. Maydeu-Olivares, . (2013). Goodness--fit assessment item response theory models (discussion). Measurement: Interdisciplinary Research Perspectives, 11, 71-137. Schellman, M., & Madison, M. J. (2024). Estimating reliability skill transition longitudinal DCMs. Journal Educational Behavioral Statistics. Templin, J., & Bradshaw, L. (2013). Measuring reliability diagnostic classification model examinee estimates. Journal Classification, 30, 251-275. von Davier M. (2008). general diagnostic model applied language testing data. British journal mathematical statistical psychology, 61(2), 287–307.
